title: 114_hr4678
content: The Act is titled the "United States Naval Station Guantanamo Bay Preservation Act". Congress finds that the United States Naval Station in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, is a strategic military asset critical to defense and regional security. The US maintains control over the area through lease agreements initiated by Congress. Military leaders support the station for various purposes including basing, logistics, disaster relief, and counter-terrorism efforts. The United States Naval Station in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, is considered a strategic location by military leaders for defense and regional security purposes. Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter and General John Kelly emphasized the importance of the base for U.S. operational and contingency plans, providing immediate access to the region and supporting a layered defense approach. The United States Naval Station in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, is crucial for securing air and maritime approaches to the United States. General Douglas Fraser highlighted its strategic importance for executing national priorities in the Caribbean, Latin America, and South America. The base also played a key role in providing temporary housing and adjudicating asylum claims after a coup in Haiti, as well as offering humanitarian disaster relief after the earthquakes in Haiti in 2010. The United States Naval Station in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, has its origins in Acts of Congress related to the Spanish-American War in 1898. Congress authorized the President to use military forces to ensure Spain relinquished control of Cuba, leading to a declaration of war and the signing of the Treaty of Paris in December 1898. The Treaty of Paris in 1898 established United States governance of Cuba, with Congress granting the President authority to return control of the island to its people. This led to the negotiation of the Guantanamo Lease Agreements for the establishment of the United States Naval Station in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. The United States Naval Station in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba was approved by President Theodore Roosevelt in 1903, citing the Act of March 2, 1901 as his authority. This allowed the United States to obtain naval station rights in Cuba. The United States obtained naval station rights in Cuba as a condition for returning control of Cuba to its people. President Theodore Roosevelt recognized the authority for this in the Act of March 2, 1901. The Treaty of Relations in 1934 did not change the Guantanamo Lease Agreements, stating they would remain in effect until modified by both countries. Congress has the power to provide for the common defense according to the U.S. Constitution. The U.S. Constitution grants Congress the power to provide for the common defense, maintain a Navy, and make rules regarding U.S. territory and property. The text chunk states that there is a prohibition on any changes to the United States jurisdiction and control over the United States Naval Station in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba without Congressional action. The text prohibits any modifications to the Guantanamo Lease Agreements without specific authorization from Congress or through a ratified statute or treaty. The term "Guantanamo Lease Agreements" refers to two agreements signed by the President of the United States in 1903 for the lease of lands in Cuba for coaling and naval stations. These agreements cannot be modified without authorization from Congress or through a ratified statute or treaty.
